coredata.dc:title: Determination of Ce valence in Rh-Ce/Al2O3 catalysts by X-ray absorption
coredata.dc:creator: Beck, D.D.
Capehart, T.W.
Hoffman, R.W.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Measurements of the cerium LIII absorption edges of Rh-Ce/Al2O3 catalysts were made to determine changes in the cerium valence produced by high temperature treatments in oxygen or hydrogen. The valences of cerium in the catalyst treated in oxygen at 900°C and CeO2 are nearly identical. However, approximately 50% of the cerium is trivalent in the catalyst treated in hydrogen at 900°C. Several local environments consistent with the reduced catalyst valence, namely, cerium alloyed with rhodium, non-stoichiometric cerium oxides, and heterogeneous mixtures of cerium oxides, are examined. We conclude that on Rh-Ce/Al2O3 treated in hydrogen at 900°C, Ce exists as a mixture of Ce2O3 and CeAlO3. Air exposure at 25°C converts the Ce2O3 portion to CeO2.

The valences of cerium in the catalyst treated in oxygen at 900CC and CeO2 are nearly identical. However, approximately 50% of the cerium is trivalent in the calalyst treated in hydrogen at 900CC, Several local environments consistent with the reduced catalyst valence, namely, cerium alloyed with rhodium, non- stoichiometric cerium oxides, and heterogeneous mixtures of cerium oxides, are examined. Introduction Automotive catalysts are frequently subjected to repeated excursions into oxidizing and reducing con- ditions [1]. In Rh-containing catalysts, the perform- ance is enhanced by the addition of several weight percent of Ce to the alumina support [2]. The pre- cise mechanism (s) for these beneficial effects are not known. However, several properties of Ce in three- way catalysts have been suggested to be involved in beneficially effecting the performance and durability of the catalyst. For instance, previous work has sug- gested that the addition of Ce inhibits the conversion of O-A1203 and y-A12O3 to u-AI2O3 at relatively high temperatures, thereby inhibiting the sintering of the supported noble metals [3,4]. Under a reducing en- vironment at relatively high temperature (9000 C), direct interaction between a supported noble metal (i.e. Pt) and Ce can occur, leading to compound for- mation (Pt5Ce) [31. A direct strong metal support interaction (SMSI) between the supported noble metal and Ce may occur under reducing conditions, modifying the sintering ability of the noble metal and the reactivity of the catalyst in the exhaust gas en- vironment [5]. Researchers have also suggested that oxides of Ce provide a source of oxygen during the brief excursions when the exhaust is stoichiometri- cally reducing [6,7]. This latter property of Ce is thought to involve the decomposition of CeO2 to form lower valence oxides in a reducing environ- ment at high temperature. The reducible nature of Ce oxide is therefore be- lieved to play an important role in influencing the performance and durability of the catalyst. Conse- quently, a determination of Ce valence as a function of treatment in various oxidizing and reducing en- vironments can provide some insight about the be- havior of Ce in the catalyst and its effect on activity and durability. Previously, X-ray absorption mea- surements of the L111 edges have been nsed to deter- mine the valence of a number of rare earth com- pounds [8 10]. This is especially true of Ce compounds where there has been an intensive effort to measure the valence and the related 4f occupation number. Much of the work on Ce has been moti- vated by the observation of mixed valency in the a phase of the metal [Il] and a number of compounds [12,13] and alloys [14,15]. The origin of the L111 edge in Ce is the 2P3/2 5d5,2312 transition. Its intensity is the result of the high density of unoccupied 3d states. For formally trivalent Ce compounds with an electronic config 207 0 009-26 14/89/$ 03.50 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. (North-Holland Physics Publishing Division) 7July 1989 Volume 159, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS uration of 4f (5d,6s) the L,11 edge consists of a sin- gle intense peak just above threshold associated with the transition 2p64f (5d,6s)3 /2p54f (5d,6s)4. In contrast, for a number of other Ce compounds (in- cluding a-Ce), a second transition is found approx- imately 10 eV above the trivalent peak. The presence of both peaks in the edge spectra from these com- pounds is typically interpreted as being due to ho- mogeneous mixed valence, i.e. a quantum mechan- ical combination of the 4f (5d,6s)3 and 4f (5d,6s)4 initial electronic configurations on the same atom. The higher energy peak is associated with the tran- sition 2p64f ( 5d,6s ~ 2p54f ( 5d,6s ) ~ occurring in the absence of a 4f screening electron, as depicted in fig. 1. Indeed, calculations by Herbst and Wilkins have shown that the measured energy difference is appropriate for the screening effect of the 4f electron on these 2p-.. 3d transition in Ce [16]. Still, the 4f screening electron may result from the excitation process (final state effect), instead of resulting from the valence (initial state effect). While final state ef- fects appear negligible in Eu, Sm, Tm, and Yb com- pounds where the observed valence spans the full range of allowed values from 4f to 4f , in Ce the valence saturates around 3.5 even in formally tetra- valent compounds [8 10,13]. This persistence of two peaks in the Ce L15, edge spectra seriously raises the issue of how much of the high energy peak is due to mixed valence and how much results from the ex- citation process. Indeed, the energy of the 2p64f ( 5d,6s )~ * 2p64f (5d,6s)4 transition, which originates from the tetravalent Ce, is calculated to be very close to the trivalent L111 transition. This issue has recently been addressed theoretically and the conclusion is that only a small fraction, perhaps 10% of the high energy transition in Ce results from final state shake up [14]. If this is true, the ratio of the strengths of the two peaks appearing in the Ce L11, spectra is a reliable measure of the initial electronic configuration. This ability to determine the initial electronic con- figuration using the Ce L,1, edge and the resulting in- ferences concerning the chemical state of Ce is de- scribed in this report. We relate these measured electronic configurations to an assigned spectro- scopic valence and deduce which stoichiometries are consistent with the catalyst composition, and the known chemical reactivity of Ce. And, although we use these measurement-derived valences to charac- terize the nature of the Ce bond, we do not identify them with a bond ionicity, i.e. a net charge transfer between atoms. Later in this report, the relationship between this spectroscopic valence and the chemical valence for Ce and its compounds, in particular CeO2, is discussed briefly. A thorough discussion of this re- lationship can be found in the recent review by Baer and Schneider [17]. 2. Experimental aspects The catalyst used in this investigation consisted of 0.5 wt% rhodium and 5 wt% cerium supported on A12O3, and was prepared in the following manner. First, 750 g of alumina spheres (W.R. Grace low bulk density alumina, 3.2 mm diameter, 110 m2/g, 1.1 ml/g pore volume, mostly O-phase) were combined with a solution of 116.2 g Ce(N03)6H30 in 750 ml of water. The spheres were dried overnight and then calcined in flowing air (1 SCFH) for 4 h at 500 C. A 100 g portion of this lot was then treated with 1.505 g [Rh(NH5)6JC13 in 100 ml of water. Two sample pellets were prepared by treatment at 900G C in either flowing 5% 03/N2 or 5% H3/N3 for I h. After treatment, each sample was cooled to room temperature and then stored in air. Due to the sub- sequent air exposure and the reactivity of Ce to air, these designations refer to the treatment and not necessarily the chemical state of these samples. The effect of sample handling on these results is dis- cussed later in this report, Two reference com- pounds were used for comparison with the catalyst samples. One compound was prepared by mixing 10 wt% CeO2 with A12O3 at room temperature, which was pressed into a pellet and treated at 500 C in 5% O3/N2 flowing at 100 SCCM. A second compound, Ce(C3H3O2)3 4H20, was obtained from Alfa. Measurements of the Ce L,1, absorption edges on the two samples and the reference compounds were made using the X-11 beamline at the National Syn- chrotron Light Source. The two-crystal monochrom- ator fitted with Si(220) crystals covered the energy range from 4 to 20 key. The L,1, edge of (nearly) trivalent cerous acetate was used to calibrate the monochromator to 5.723 keV. All absorption spec- tra were recorded in the transmission mode with the samples in air at room temperature. In addition, X- ray diffraction measurements were obtained for the reference compounds and treated catalyst samples in order to identify crystallite phases. 3. Results and discussion 3.1. Cerium valence from near edge absorption Fig. 2 reports the L,1, near edge absorption spectra for Rh-Ce/A1205 treated in oxygen at 900 C, Rh-Ce/ A1203 treated in hydrogen at 900 C, and two ref- erence compounds. These normalized absorption spectra are produced by (I) subtracting a quadratic background, fit to the post-edge region, from the ab- sorption spectrum, and (2) normalizing the edge jumps to unity. As shown in the figure, the resulting near edge spectra for CeO2 and both of the treated catalysts show the double-peaked structure typical of mixed valence Ce compounds. As anticipated, the spectrum obtained for cerous acetate has a single in- tense peak just above the absorption edge. In order to determine the spectroscopie valence from these spectra, the following method was used. The near edge was fit to the sum of the standard (1 /x) xtan [2(E 1)/o] formula, which assumes a constant density of final states and matrix elements [18], and two Lorentzians, one for each possible 4f valence configuration. All spectra were fit with the same values for the edge energy, ~L, and width, o. The contributions of the 4f and 4f configurations were estimated by the integrated strengths of the resulting Lorentzian peaks. The weight of the 4f configura- tion is given by v=4f /(4f0+4f1), and the core- sponding Ce valence of 3 + a is shown to the left of each spectrum. As indicated in fig. 2, while the measured valence of eerous acetate is near its formal valence of +3, CeO2 supported on A1203 is far from its formal te- travalent state. One may argue that the observed low valence is attributable to an interaction between CeO3 and the A1303 support, but we note that the X-ray absorption spectrum reported elsewhere [19] for bulk CeO3 is identical to that for Ce03/A13O3 re- ported here. Since the insulating, non-magnetic properties of CeO2 can be readily understood as due to tetravalent Ce and a filled O 2p band, the asser- tion that it does not have an integral valence may e C a a. o 4 Q 0 3 2 Fig. 2. However, several mechanisms have been proposed which reconcile mixed valency with an insulating, non-magnetic ground state in CeO3 [20,21]. Basically, these involve hybridization of the 4f and (os,6p) states which effectively delo- calize the 4f electron allowing it to participate in bond formation. This presumed 4f delocalization preserves the view that the spectroscopically deter- mined valence measures the initial state electronic configuration even io compounds like bulk CeO2. However, this view implicitly acknowledges that the 4f occupancy is not directly related to bond ionicity. We accept these arguments and assume that the measured valence of 3.55 reflects the initial elec- tronic configuration of CeO3/A13O3 and bulk CeO3. Comparing the results for the reference compounds to the treated catalysts reveals that the valence of Ce in oxidized Rh-Cc/A13O3 (3.50) is nearly identical with CeO3/A13O3 (3.55). Therefore, following treat- ment of Rh-Ce/Al303 in oxygen at 900 C, most of the cerium in the catalyst is present as CeO2 (>95%). This conclusion is supported by the observation of large (>50 nm diameter) CeO2 crystallites by XRD. However, following treatment of Rh-Ce/A13O3 in hydrogen at 900G C, the valence of Ce is significantly lower (3.29). The local structural environment of Ce in the reduced sample is thus different from the oxidized sample and is discussed in section 3.2. 3.2. Cerium valence and stoichiometry Initially, the Ce valence observed in the reduced Rh-Ce/A13O3 (3.29) is consistent with a number of different stoichiometries. Clearly, the observed va- lence can be explained by a heterogeneous mixture of a trivalent Ce oxide, such as CeAIO3 or Ce3O3, and the quadrivalent oxide CeO3. Competing alter- natives are: the presence of y-Ce metal (trivalent), a direct interaction between Ce and Rh possibly in- volving compound formation, the formation of a ho- mogeneous non-stoichiometric oxide CeO3 -~ or some combination of these possibilities. We note that the catalyst treated in hydrogen at 900 C was subsequently exposed to air at room tem- perature prior to the X-ray absorption measurement. Thus, the possibility of metallic y-Ce can be imme- diately disregarded since metallic Ce is completely oxidized in air at room temperature. And, while compound or alloy formation between Rh and Ce cannot be excluded, any contribution of alloying can be shown to be small. This conclusion results from the previously determined valences of CeRh3 and CeRh3 intermetallics [14] shown in fig. 3 along with a number of other compounds. Even if all the Rh was incorporated in CeRh3 this would account for less than 7~/q of the Ce atoms and the resultsng average valence, assuming a heterogeneous mixture of CeO3 and CeRh3, would be higher than the observed value. Higher Ce content alloys could provide a lower va- lence, but the reactivity of the alloy to oxidation in- creases. Since a small CeRh3 particle is not expected to be stable in air, a more concentrated stable Ce al- loy is unlikely. So, despite the similarity between the near edge spectra of the iaternietallics and the re- duced catalyst, these processes alone cannot explain the spectroscopically measured valence of the re- duced catalyst. Spectroscopically determined valences for several Ce compounds, Rh-Ce/Al20, oxidized at 900 C, and Rh-Ce/A130, reduced at 900 C. 210 Volume 159, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 July 1989 natives, a homogeneous non-stoichiometric oxide CeO3 and a heterogeneous mixture of trivalent cerium oxides and CeO3 is more difficult. For while the valences of the stoichiometric oxides are known, the dependence of valence on the oxygen deficiency has not been measured to our knowledge. However, in recent work by Yagci, the oxidation of Ce films was studied by X-ray absorption [22]. In that study, thin Ce films (300 400 A) were oxidized by expo- sure to dry oxygen and air. Oxidation initiated with dry oxygen at room temperature produced only Ce3O3. Furthermore, the resulting Ce3O, was stable to subsequent exposure to air. In contrast, the films oxidized in air were completely converted to CeO3 in 4 to 5 days. In an XPS study of the oxidation of Ce polycrystalline foil at 27 C, Koel and co-workers concluded that oxidation takes place by the forma- tion of a thick layer of Ce3O3, ending in a layer of CeO3 on the outer surface [23]. The absence of sta- ble non-stoiehiometrie cerium oxides in these re- ported studies suggests that formation of such com- pounds in the treated catalyst samples is not likely. Consequently, cerium on the reduced catalyst more likely exists in the form of a heterogeneous mixture of stoiehiometric oxides (Ce3O3, CeA1O3, and CeO3). Further support for this interpretation can be found in our present data. In homogeneous mixed valence systems the 4f and 4f peak positions shift and line- shapes change significantly as the valence varies be- tween 3.1 and 3.4 (see fig. 2 in ref. [14]). Hence, a near edge spectrum cannot generally be deconvo- luted as the sum of two other spectra which bracket its valence. On the other hand, the absorption spec- trum of a heterogeneous mixture can always be re- produced by the appropriately weighted sum of the absorption spectra of its constituent compounds. And, as demonstrated in fig. 4, the near edge spectra of the reduced catalyst are accurately represented by the appropriately weighted sum of the spectra for CeO3 and trivalent cerous acetate (which should be nearly identical to the near edge spectra of CeAIO3 or Ce3O3). We note that XRD measurement of the Rh-Ce/ A12O3 catalyst treated in hydrogen at 900 C indi- cates the presence of CeAIO, erystallites. Detection of CeA1O3 in Pd-Ce/A13O3 and Pt-Ce/AI2O, cata- lysts following reduction at 920 C has also been re- ported by Shyu [23]. Formation of CeA1O3 has also been observed when CeO3/A13O3 supported cata- lysts were reduced at 950 C [241. These tempera- tures are significantly lower than the reduction tem- perature required to synthesize CeAlO3 from cerium nitrate and aluminum nitrate [25]. In this synthesis, reduction temperatures of 10000 C were required be- fore X-ray diffraction or electron spin resonance (ESR) showed evidence of trivalent CeA1O3. Certainly, the present experimental results are consistent with the suggestion that Ce can be incor- porated with the support in the form of CeAIO3 as a result of reduction at high temperature. From the near edge spectra CeAIO3 and Ce3O3 cannot be dis- tinguished. In addition, the XRD measurement can- not be used to account for all of the Ce: CeO3 and Ce2O3 may also be present in disordered form or in small domains (<5 nm in diameter). Consequently, the distribution of the trivalent Ce forms remains in question. X-ray diffraction and ESR results on sim- ilar systems, however, suggest the majority of the tri- valent oxide is CeAIO3. Combining the oxidation properties of Ce films and the accurate representa- tion of the near edge spectrum by a sum of a trivalent edge and the CeO3 edge provides a compelling ar- gument for the reduced sample being composed of a heterogeneous mixture of two oxides. Least-squares fits of the near edge spectra of the reduced and oxidized catalysts using a weighted sum of the spectra of the formally quadrivalent Ce in CeO2 and the trivalent Ce in Ce(C,H,02 ) - ~H2O. 5.72 5.74 5.76 5.78 Energy(KoV) 211 Volume 159, number 2,3 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 7 July 1989 described, the reduced catalyst is found to consist of 49% CeO2 and 51% trivalent cerium oxide. Fur- thermore, the trivalent oxide is more likely in the form of CeAIO3 than Ce3O3. We note that prior to air exposure, the average cer- ium valence in the hydrogen-treated Rh-Ce/AI3O3 catalyst was probably near 3. This conclusion is sup- ported by in situ X-ray photoelectron spectroscopie measurements of the same catalyst treated in hydro- gen at 900 C [27]. In that study, treatment of the catalyst in hydrogen at lower temperatures (500, 600, 700, 800, and 900 C) converted CeO3 to Ce3O3 on the support. For samples treated at 800 C or a lower temperature, subsequent exposure to air at 25 C re- sults in conversion to CeO3. However, air exposure of the sample treated at 900 C produced a mixture of trivalent and quadrivalent Ce forms. Using XRD, CeA1O3 was detected only in this latter sample. Shyu and Otto have reported that treatment in oxygen at ~ 500 C is required to convert CeA1O3 to CeO3 in Pt-Ce/A13O3, whereas treatment in oxygen at ? 800 C is required to complete the same conver- sion in the absence of Pt [28]. Based on these ob- servations, the hydrogen-treated Rh-Ce/AI3O, cat- alyst studied here probably contained a combination of CeAIO, and Ce3O3. Subsequent exposure to air caused the oxidation of the Ce3O, portion to form CeO3, while the CeAIO, portion was unaffected. The presence of Rh on the catalyst might serve to catalyze CeO3 decomposition in a reducing environ- ment, or restoration of CeO3 in an oxidizing envi- ronment. Shyu and Otto have suggested that the presence of a noble metal catalyzes the bulk oxida- tion of CeAIO, to CeO3 [28]. As described previ- ously, alloying between Rh and Ce has been dem- onstrated, suggesting intimate contact between Rh and Ce in the hydrogen-treated catalyst is possible. Indeed, in EXAFS studies of Rh on another redu- cible oxide support, TiO3, a Rh Ti shell has been de- tected [29]. Although we cannot exclude this inter- esting possibility, we have found no evidence supporting Rh Ce proximity in these treated sam- ples. Perhaps the most decisive future experiment to resolve the question of a direct interaction would in- volve an EXAFS analysis concentrating on the con- tributions from the support to the Rh radial struc- ture factor. By repeating the analysis for cerium promoted and cerium free catalysts in controlled at- mospheres, the prospects for resolving this issue would be enhanced. Finally, the amount of CeO3 which is decomposed under a realistic exhaust environment should be examined in a future experiment. The typical auto- motive exhaust environment alternates between a rich (slightly reducing) and lean (slightly oxi- dizing) stoichiometry on a timescale of 0.5 to 2 Hz [I]. The portion of CeO3 which is converted to the trivalent Ce compound under these conditions is un- known but is expected to be relatively small unless special circumstances arise (i.e. prolonged exposure to reducing stoichiometry for prolonged periods). 4. Conclusions Measurement of the Ce L,,1 absorption edge struc- ture using synchrotron radiation can provide a use- ful means for characterizing the chemical state of Ce in a model automotive three-way catalyst consisting of Rh and Ce supported on A1303, Following treat- ment of the catalyst in oxygen at 900 C, the ab- sorption edge structure indicates that all of the Ce is present in the tetravalent state, consistent with the presence of CeO3. Following treatment of the cata- lyst in hydrogen at 900 C, followed by exposure to air at 25 a C, approximately 50% of the cerium is tri- valent. Such a large fraction of trivalent Ce can be explained best by the formation of a mixture of CeA1O3 and Ce3O3 during reduction, of which the CeA1O3 portion is stable to air exposure. The mea- sured oxidation states and deduced stoichiometries provide some insight about the behavior of Ce in re- ducing and oxidizing environments, and in partic- ular about the involvement of Ce in the storing and releasing of oxygen during cycles of high tempera- ture oxidation and reduction. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Measurements of the cerium LIII absorption edges of Rh-Ce/Al2O3 catalysts were made to determine changes in the cerium valence produced by high temperature treatments in oxygen or hydrogen. The valences of cerium in the catalyst treated in oxygen at 900°C and CeO2 are nearly identical. However, approximately 50% of the cerium is trivalent in the catalyst treated in hydrogen at 900°C. Several local environments consistent with the reduced catalyst valence, namely, cerium alloyed with rhodium, non-stoichiometric cerium oxides, and heterogeneous mixtures of cerium oxides, are examined. We conclude that on Rh-Ce/Al2O3 treated in hydrogen at 900°C, Ce exists as a mixture of Ce2O3 and CeAlO3. Air exposure at 25°C converts the Ce2O3 portion to CeO2.
